description.narrative:
In January and February of 2015, the southern districts of Malawi experienced higher than normal rainfall, which provoked massive floods. The floods covered approximately 64,000 hectares (640 sq. km), wiping out the season’s crops for this largely agricultural region, killing 176 people and displacing 230,000.. The remote southern district of Nsanje was hardest hit, with a loss of 1,500 hectares of crops and 41% of its population displaced.
This region already suffers from food insecurity.The effects of climate change mean that the farmers are either contending with drought or flooding. Some farmers have abandoned farming in favor of cutting down trees to sell for fuel, leading to the loss of approximately 95% of the topsoil in the area. The result is that grassland which supports livestock is disappearing, and harvests have been declining as the population increases.
This latest catastrophic flood has exacerbated the problems of poverty and food insecurity in the district, highlighting the fragility of their economy by wiping out their crops for the year. Even if able to replant this year, the coming dry season means that they will not have access to the water the crops need to have another chance at a harvest this year. For the forseeable future, this flood/drought pattern is expected to continue.

This project's goal is to build 48 treadle pump-operated irrigation wells in Nsanje District, one of the most heavily affected districts to irrigate approximately 48 hectares in two agricultural schemes. Access to well water during the upcoming dry season will allow subsistence farmers to replace the harvest they lost in the floods and improve their food security in the future by increasing the number of harvest cycles per year from one to three. Because the wells are constructed with cement bonded brick they will be resilient to future floods.
The project relies on community participation. The project has been jointly designed by All Hands and the Muona Foundation, in consultation with local chiefs, local government officials, and the Agricultural Extension office. Beneficiaries will participate by supplying materials (sand) and labor.
